content: "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/first100days/2009/03/18/obama-drops-controversial-health-care-plan-wounded-veterans/" "In considering the third-party billing issue, the administration was seeking to maximize the resources available for veterans," White House press secretary Robert Gibbs said Wednesday in a written statement. "However, the president listened to concerns raised by the [veteran service organizations] that this might, under certain circumstances, affect veterans' and their families' ability to access health care. "Therefore, the president has instructed that its consideration be dropped," Gibbs said. "We are glad that President Obama listened to the strong objections raised by The American Legion and veterans everywhere about this unfair plan," Cmdr. David K. Rehbein of the American Legion said. "We thank the administration for its proposed increase in the VA budget and we are always available to assist by providing guidance to ensure a veterans health are system that is worthy of the heroes that use it."
reply: "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/first100days/2009/03/18/obama-drops-controversial-health-care-plan-wounded-veterans/" "In considering the third-party billing issue, the administration was seeking to maximize the resources available for veterans," White House press secretary Robert Gibbs said Wednesday in a written statement. "However, the president listened to concerns raised by the [veteran service organizations] that this might, under certain circumstances, affect veterans' and their families' ability to access health care. "Therefore, the president has instructed that its consideration be dropped," Gibbs said. "We are glad that President Obama listened to the strong objections raised by The American Legion and veterans everywhere about this unfair plan," Cmdr. David K. Rehbein of the American Legion said. "We thank the administration for its proposed increase in the VA budget and we are always available to assist by providing guidance to ensure a veterans health are system that is worthy of the heroes that use it."
title: Obama: Keep VA healthcare as it is.

title: Obama: Keep VA healthcare as it is.

content: Ah but there you are incorrect. No priority 7 and 8 Vets were cut at every VA hospital. I worked at the Phoenix VA and saw a lot of Vets who were 7's and 8's getting their treatment there, as a matter of fact I worked with one. He had cancer and had to have a colostomy bag for awhile and go through radiation and chemo treatments and he had it all done at the VA and he is an 8 and still being treated there. It had more to do with the size of the VA hospitals whether or not they could service 7 or 8 Vets. The reason they were not serviced at every VA is if they had the staff to handle it. Another thing that changed under Pres. Bush's watch was the way funds are used, it used to be that if a Veteran was from PA his VA there would recieve funding based on his use of that VA no matter if he went to another VA in another state, now the funds follow the Vet. If the Vet from PA gets treated in Phoenix then funds are transfered to Phoenix for the care he recieved there. The VA also saw the biggest budget increases under Pres. Bush, than they had ever recieved before. I know because I worked there.
reply: Ah but there you are incorrect. No priority 7 and 8 Vets were cut at every VA hospital. "Veterans assigned to Priority Groups 8e or 8g are not eligible for enrollment as a result of the enrollment restriction which suspended enrolling new high-income veterans who apply for care after January 16, 2003. content: Gee, oddly enough, they are still being enrolled and treated at the Phoenix VA. There are always exceptions to the rules. For what it is worth, I feel Pres. content: I don't think you realize you were looking at the largest middle class tax hike in history. First dumping disabled vets on private insurers would have sent insurance premiums sky-rocketing. That would force some marginaly profitable employers to drop employee health care. Causing the pool of premium payers to decrease further raising health insurance premiums. Second, for those of us who still have employer subsidized health insurance, Obama proposes taxing the amount the employer contributes as ordinary income. This proposal alone is a huge increase in taxes on the middle class. The lib/socialist solution to every problem is to raise taxes. Yes we can!
reply: I don't think you realize you were looking at the largest middle class tax hike in history. First dumping disabled vets on private insurers would have sent insurance premiums sky-rocketing. That would force some marginaly profitable employers to drop employee health care. Causing the pool of premium payers to decrease further raising health insurance premiums. Second, for those of us who still have employer subsidized health insurance, Obama proposes taxing the amount the employer contributes as ordinary income. This proposal alone is a huge increase in taxes on the middle class. The lib/socialist solution to every problem is to raise taxes. Yes we can!

content: quote: karlhungusjr: What about cutting out priority groups 7 and 8 from VA healthcare?? He didn't "study" the idea then listen to the legion and change his mind. He just cut them all out. Actually enrollment was closed. That's different the being "cut out." I'm cat 8 and still receiving care. Any veteran in crisis can receive treatment from the VA. Any veteran who meets the criteria of the means test can receive treatment from the VA. Not the "lifetime health care" the recruiters used to talk about but not being "cut out" either. BTW, I wasn't in the VA system when Carter was President. I don't know what he did. I enrolled during the Clinton Administration when the VA had open enrollment. I was originally cat 7 then bumped to cat 8.
quote: karlhungusjr: What about cutting out priority groups 7 and 8 from VA healthcare?? He didn't "study" the idea then listen to the legion and change his mind. He just cut them all out.
reply: Actually enrollment was closed. That's different the being "cut out." I'm cat 8 and still receiving care. Any veteran in crisis can receive treatment from the VA. Any veteran who meets the criteria of the means test can receive treatment from the VA. Not the "lifetime health care" the recruiters used to talk about but not being "cut out" either. BTW, I wasn't in the VA system when Carter was President. I don't know what he did. I enrolled during the Clinton Administration when the VA had open enrollment. I was originally cat 7 then bumped to cat 8.

That, so-called, myth was given to those who would stay in and retire and that was just that, a myth. content: quote: Originally posted by karlhungusjr: "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/first100days/2009/03/18/obama-drops-controversial-health-care-plan-wounded-veterans/" "In considering the third-party billing issue, the administration was seeking to maximize the resources available for veterans," White House press secretary Robert Gibbs said Wednesday in a written statement. "However, the president listened to concerns raised by the [veteran service organizations] that this might, under certain circumstances, affect veterans' and their families' ability to access health care. "Therefore, the president has instructed that its consideration be dropped," Gibbs said. "We are glad that President Obama listened to the strong objections raised by The American Legion and veterans everywhere about this unfair plan," Cmdr. David K. Rehbein of the American Legion said. "We thank the administration for its proposed increase in the VA budget and we are always available to assist by providing guidance to ensure a veterans health are system that is worthy of the heroes that use it." LOL ... While I'm damned glad to see this dropped, Gibbs must be high on something when he says this: quote: "In considering the third-party billing issue, the administration was seeking to maximize the resources available for veterans," White House press secretary Robert Gibbs said Wednesday in a written statement. "However, the president listened to concerns raised by the [veteran service organizations] that this might, under certain circumstances, affect veterans' and their families' ability to access health care. How anyone can rationalize third party billing as giving Vets more resources defies logic. What Obama listened to were Democratic senators such as Patty Murray who told him, via Eric Shinseki, that if he sent that proposal to Congress, it would be dead on arrival ...
